Transcript: Wednesday  Bird--  Just received your special written Sunday. Am so glad you took a day off and went to Dallas.   This has been a most pleasant and useful week.  Some talk of the President calling Congress back late in November. We are all hoping it won’t be necessary-- Lyndon
Title: Postcard, Lyndon Johnson to Lady Bird Taylor, October 24, 1934
Creator: Lyndon Baines Johnson
Abstract: LBJ sends Lady Bird a picture postcard of the Lincoln Memorial with a note saying he is glad she took a day off and went to Dallas. He comments that he has had a very pleasant and useful week and that the President may call Congress back in November.
Rights: The LBJ Presidential Library has no information about the original source of this item. Copyright restrictions may apply.
Collection: The Personal Papers of Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson are a collection of correspondence between Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson that spans 1934 through 1968. During the Johnsons’ years in the White House, Dorothy Territo, a staff assistant who maintained files of high historical value, as well as family and genealogical material, had custody of the collection. In 1969, the files she kept came to Austin as part of President Johnson’s papers, which he had deeded to the U.S. government in August 1965.This collection includes the courtship letters between Lyndon Johnson and Claudia "Lady Bird" Taylor, from the period between their introduction and their marriage, September – November 1934.
Citation: “Postcard, Lyndon Johnson to Lady Bird Taylor, October 24, 1934,” Personal Papers of Lyndon B. and Lady Bird Johnson, LBJ Presidential Library, Dear Bird: The 1934 Courtship Letters, accessed November 27, 2016, http://archives.lbjlibrary.org/items/show/416.
